nodes.bodyText: It's unclear to me if it's intentional (or desirable) that a task update would previously cause these values to change once a query was promoted to the reserved pool. If so, it's easy enough to modify this PR to handle that as well- just need to know the intended behavior in that situation.

Since it's unclear what the intended or correct interaction between resource over-commit and the reserved pool should be in this scenario, I've opted to preserve the current effective behavior by modifying the memory limits for resource over-commit queries as part of their memory pool change.

This change makes sense to me. The limit on resource over commit should be all available memory in the pool. We don't want to fail without using the entire pool. If the reserve pool happens to be larger then we want to use it.
I don't see that as being common but whatever :-)
Would this need to be volatile for needsMemoryLimitsInitialized to return an up to date value without synchronization with other threads?

Ah, so you spotted it! I figured someone might. If it was more critical to avoid redundant initializations, you might indeed want to make it volatile (and I'm happy to do so if you feel strongly about it). The goal here is simply to avoid repeatedly contending for the QueryContext since all memory updates for the query also contend for that lock (very heavily, I might add). This is more of a "best effort" and it's not critical to definitely observe latest state since the failure mode is a redundant update (just like what happens today). Happy to change it that's what you'd prefer.
OK, QueryContext is almost definitely safely published so we can rely on the default value.
Decided to make it volatile anyway since clearly this was going to be a recurring feedback item.

This statement looks quite weird.  if resource resourceOverCommit is true, then `setResourceOvercommit? -- looks unnecessary?
My understanding is we call setResourceOvercommit() to reset memory limits based on the pool assignment. If that's the case maybe elaborate a bit in the comment? e.g.
While resourceOverCommit is already set to true, we still call setResourceOvercommit() to 
reset the memory limits based on the new pool assignment

-- Just want to double check on this. I can edit the comment when merging it, since it's a very small change.

Alternatively, you can just do what is done in the PrestoSQL repo right? https://github.com/prestosql/presto/pull/6349/files#diff-f218331177a9762b996c0276315db720a7b987ff7a0455aca45993db22a06b15R272 :)
Actually, since it's confirmed by PrestoSQL side PR. I will just merge this :) . Leave minor comment tweak/ refactor as future work :)
curious: is this also Guarded this? -- or we are based on benign data race?
